The  Project  will  benefit  farmers  in  five  districts  with  about  2.75 
million  poor  people  and  overall  poverty  rate  of  66%—almost  twice 
the  national  average.  The  components  for  farmer  empowerment, 
development  of  national  and  local  information  resources,  and 
support  for  agricultural  innovation  development  and  dissemination 
are expected to benefit these poor people by facilitating agricultural 
and marketing innovations and increasing incomes. The Project will 
target  villages  in  which  75%  of  the  households  are  poor.  Typical 
project  beneficiaries  will  be  poor  farmers  who  have  low  productive

investments will directly raise the incomes or food security of about 
400,000  poor  households  to  levels  above  the  poverty  line.  Women 
will directly benefit from active involvement in the planning of village 
investments,  capacity  building,  and  targeting  of  village  investments

III. 

BACKGROUND 

A. 

Sector Description 

1. 

The Agriculture Sector 

ADB’s 2001 country operational strategy (COS), poverty assessment in Indonesia,4 and 
3. 
1998  agriculture  sector  strategy  study  and  update  in  2000,5  provide  the  overall  context  for 
agricultural  and  rural  development  in  Indonesia.  Agriculture  provides  employment  to  a  large 
percentage of Indonesia’s population; substantially meets the country’s food requirements; and 
provides  most  raw  materials  for  manufacturing,  particularly  for  exports.  However,  agricultural 
growth has stagnated and lagged behind growth of the nonagriculture sectors. Policy distortions 
have constrained growth. While recent initiatives to deregulate the sector have improved sector 
incentives for farmers, (i) inadequate technology development, (ii) deficient physical and social 
infrastructure, (iii) weak institutions, and (iv) improper incentives continue to restrict the ability of 
farmers to improve incomes. 
 
Constraints  are  particularly  severe  in  marginal  rainfed  areas,  particularly  in  the  drier 
4. 
eastern half of Indonesia. Technology development for these areas has lagged far behind that 
for well-endowed irrigated areas. Much government agricultural support is planned centrally and 
does  not  adequately  address  location-specific,  village-level  causes  of  low  and  unstable  yields 
and  inadequate  market  access.  Inadequate  horizontal  communication  and  vertical  access  to 
information reduce the access of farmers to technologies, potential markets for their products, 
market prices, input sources and prices, and potential solutions to farm problems. 
 
The  Government  recently  has  been  taking  steps  to  improve  the  agricultural  policy 
5. 
environment  and  to  incorporate  larger  agricultural  and  rural  development  goals  within  a

2. 

Poverty and Agriculture 

Agricultural  growth  and  rural  development  have  always  been  key  to  directly  reducing 
7. 
poverty in Indonesia. The decline in poverty during the 1970s was due in large part to the rapid 
growth  in  agricultural  production  and  the  resulting  job  creation  in  off-farm  employment  in 
agricultural processing, transport, and trade. Poverty reduction impacts have been low since the 
mid-1980s  as  agricultural  productivity  stagnated  and  returns  to  farming  declined.  During  the 
economic crisis, however, agriculture provided a safety net to workers shifting out of declining 
sectors.  Despite  the  declining  importance  of  agriculture  in  the  economy,  about  58%  of 
Indonesia’s poor derive their income primarily from agriculture. About 40% of those engaged in 
agriculture are poor (the highest poverty rate in any economic sector in Indonesia). 
 
8. 
Similarly,  rural  development—which  is  centered  upon  agriculture—has  important 
implications  for  poverty  reduction.  Almost  90%  of  the  rural  poor  and  near  poor  derive  their 
income primarily from agriculture. Quality of life of the rural poor is very low. Eighty percent of 
the  rural  population  have  less  than  5  years  of  formal  education.  One  third  of  rural  infants  are 
malnourished,  while  more  than  50%  of  rural  women  suffer  from  micronutrient  deficiencies. 
These  low  living  standards  prevent  the  rural  poor  from  accessing  the  benefits  of  economic 
growth—bad  health  and  illiteracy  renders  them  unsuitable  for  many  forms  of  employment. 
Therefore,  apart  from  the  direct  impact  of  improvements  on  quality  of  life  that  is  normally 
associated with an increase in incomes, rural development will also increase access of the poor 
to the benefits of economic growth by improving quality of life. 
 
9. 
For  poor  farmers,  the  constraints  identified  by  ADB’s  COS  manifest  themselves  as 
impediments  to  adopting  production  and  marketing  innovations  necessary  to  engage  in 
commercial production and access the benefits of wider economic growth. While technology has 
been developed for some upland and rainfed areas, many marginal and rainfed areas typically 
inhabited by poor farmers lag behind well-endowed areas in terms of options for technological

B. 

Lessons Learned 

ADB’s  country  synthesis  of  lessons  learned  from  projects  in  Indonesia7  and  sector 
10. 
synthesis  of  lessons  learned  from  projects  under  agriculture  and  natural  resources8  are 
particularly relevant for the Project. ADB’s agriculture projects in Indonesia have not performed 
as  well  as  projects  in  many  other  sectors  because  they  are  complex  and  target  diverse 
environments.  Overly  rigid  implementing  arrangements  and  design  features  often  impede 
project  success  because  they  do  not  allow  the  flexibility  to  adjust  to  evolving  economic, 
technical,  and  social  circumstances  and  local  conditions.  Well-defined  project  formats  and 
procedures  ensure  acceptable  standards  for  procurement,  financial  management,  and  project 
quality.  Implementation  arrangements  must  be  based  on  the  realistic  capacities  of  sector 
institutions if project benefits are to be sustained beyond project completion because no means 
remain to replicate and sustain project activities. 
 
11. 
Community participation improves project quality, targeting, and sustainability, but has to 
be well supported through training and technical support. Community control over project funds 
induces communities to allocate resources according to priorities and potential, but the transfer 
of  funds  to  communities  without  social  preparation  has  led  to  unsatisfactory  results.9 
Communities  cannot  be  left  to  their  own  resources  to  design  and  implement  projects.  Skilled 
technical  and  social  facilitation  and  backstopping  from  external  sources  is  crucial  for  the 
success  of  community  projects.  Experience  has  also  shown  that  group  mobilization  is  most 
effective  if  a  member  of  the  local  community  facilitates  it,  and  that  the  participation  of  women 
increases  project  effectiveness  and  sustainability.  NGOs  and  community  organizations  have 
successfully  trained  community-based  organizations  in  fund  management,  microenterprise 
management,  participatory  monitoring  and  evaluation,  marketing,  and  technology  adoption.

However, they lack the means to do so. While the Government is taking steps to fill the gaps in 
providing  public  goods  support  for  agriculture,  and  increasingly  for  nonrice  crops,  additional 
support  is  needed  to  target  village-level  public  investments  to  the  needs  of  poor  farmers,  to 
increase the availability of technologies needed by poor farmers, and to increase the access of 
poor farmers to information to support agricultural production and marketing innovations.

V. 

PROJECT JUSTIFICATION 

A. 

Economic Benefits and Impact on Poverty 

1. 

Economic Benfits 

67. 
The  Project  does  not  lend  itself  to  the  traditional  economic  analysis  of  projects. 
Quantifiable  benefits  will  arise  from  village  investments  as  increased  agricultural  incomes,  but 
because  beneficiaries  determine  investments,  inputs  and  outputs  cannot  be  accurately 
predicted. The farmer empowerment component provides capacity development of poor farmers 
to  solve  common  problems,  and  of  local  NGOs/community  organizations  to  support  farmer 
groups. Government capacity will increase through the development of information systems and 
human resources for research. The innovation component promotes a demand-driven focus for 
agricultural research and development to meet location-specific needs of poor farmers, typically 
in  marginal,  rainfed  areas  underrepresented  in  past  government  research  and  development. 
Such  benefits  are  project  objectives  for  which  input  costs  are  identifiable,  but  outputs  and 
outcomes cannot be predicted with accuracy. Studies of the economic impact of research show 
highly  positive  returns  and  technological  innovations  are  examples  of  the  public  goods  sought 
by the Project to create nonexclusionary benefits to improve poor farmers’ incomes. 
 

2. 

Impact on Poverty 

68. 
Survey  and  census  data  of  the  Central  Bureau  of  Statistics  allow  highly  cost-efficient 
targeting  of  the  poor  down  to  the  village  level  using  measures  of  consumption,  diet,  housing, 
malnutrition,  and  the  like.  The  data  show  that  rich  and  poor  communities  exist  in  most 
provinces, districts, and subdistricts; and targeting at these levels result in substantial leakage of 
benefits to the nonpoor. Targeting at the village level allows this Project to identify a beneficiary 
population in which 75% of households are poor. 
 
69. 
The Central Bureau’s statistics show simple head-count shares of the poor as (i) 75% of 
beneficiary households; (ii) 66% of households in project districts; and (iii) 12.1% of taxes based 
on  their  share  of  national  expenditure.  However,  the  75%  head  count  of  poor  households 
understates the poverty impact of the Project as it is concerned only with the share of benefits, 
while ADB’s prescribed analysis also incorporates share of costs, mostly by taxes to which the 
poor contribute only 12.1%. The analysis ratios are (i) poverty impact ratio of the net benefits to 
the poor to total net benefits, and (ii) net benefits to the poor as a ratio to project cost. 
 
70. 
The poor’s high share in benefits and low share in costs will result in a favorable poverty 
impact  ratio.  If  benefits  from  quantifiable  but  uncertain  village  investments  give  returns  in  an 
expected  range  of  15%  to  20%,  then  (i)  the  poverty  impact  ratio  ranges  from  3.7  to  1.8, 
demonstrating  a  substantial  distributional  effect  in  favor  of  the  poor;  and  (ii)  the  ratio  of  net 
benefits of the poor to the present value of project costs range from 66% to 91%. Village plans 
reviewed show typical financial internal rates of return of some 25%, to give project economic 
returns  providing  a  poverty  impact  ratio  of  about  2.5  and  net  benefits  to  the  poor  at  75%  of 
project  costs.  Though  uncertain  in  detail,  the  range  suggests  the  Project  is  soundly  poverty 
focused,  and  efficient  and  effective  in  delivering  benefits  to  the  poor.  The  poverty  impact 
assessment is discussed in greater detail in Appendix 14.

3. 

Delivery Efficiency 

71. 
Delivering  village  level  public  investments  is  more  efficient  through  the  Project’s 
proposed  mechanism:  (i)  decision  making  authority  and  implementing  responsibility  delegated 
to  farmers  themselves,  and  (ii)  funds  controlled  by  farmers  than  through  planning  by 
government  agencies  and  delivery  through  outside  contractors.  After  decentralization,  village-
level public investments are delivered through a three-stage process: (i) information gathering at 
the  village  level  through  an  extension  agent  or  field  staff  of  the  agricultural  service;  (ii) 
consolidation  of  village  information  and  central  investment  priorities  at  the  district  agricultural 
office,  development  of  investment  plans,  and  identification  of  village  investments;  and  (iii) 
delivery  of  village  investments  typically  through  contractors  supervised  by  government 
agencies.  Rough  estimates  show  that  delivering  $30,000  of  village  investments  through  the 
existing government structures would cost between $4,505 and $4,675. In contrast, the annual 
cost  of  delivering  proposed  project  investments  using  village  decision  making  with  NGO 
coordination  and  technical  backstopping  is  estimated  at  $1,648.  Cost  savings  are  achieved 
because technical backstopping is provided only as needed; information collection and planning 
at the village level have very low costs; and the cost of relaying information from the village to 
the district level, incorporating this information in a wider development planning mechanism, and 
translating this information into investment plans is avoided. 
 
B. 

Environment  

72. 
An  important  feature  of  the  Project  is  its  focus  on  developing  the  capacity  of  village 
facilitators  to  involve  farmers  in  actively  identifying  and  implementing  village  investments. 
Therefore,  the  approach  to  raising  environmental  awareness  in  the  Project  will  be  to  integrate 
environmental  assessments  into  the  formulation  of  village  investments,  rather  than  to  try  to 
impose  another  layer  of  environmental  intervention.  The  village  plans  will  take  into  account 
environmental aspects (e.g., rainfall, evaporation, soils, consumption of agrochemical) with the 
assistance  of  competent  local  expertise  identified  by  local  and  national  NGOs.  Applicable 
government  regulations  will  be  strictly  adhered  to  in  the  implementation  of  all  village 
investments.  Therefore,  the  Project  will  offer  potential  environmental  benefits  by  avoiding 
environmental  costs  resulting  from  failure  to  take  into  account  environmental  conditions  in 
selecting the right inputs for agriculture and other economic activities. 
 
C. 

Social Dimensions 

The Project will directly enhance the capacity of poor farmers to innovate in agricultural 
73. 
production  and  marketing.  Since  the  type  of  agricultural  technology  chosen  will  take  into 
consideration  local  social  and  physical  conditions  of  the  project  areas,  agricultural  production 
risk will be reduced. Vulnerable groups will, therefore be accorded security of income streams 
and welfare. The Project will work together with local village facilitators, local NGOs/community 
organizations, and competent local expertise such as district agriculture extension workers, who 
understand  the  local  social  conditions  and  who  will  use  this  knowledge  as  a  basis  for 
strengthening  participatory  development.  This  will  increase  the  participation  of  the  poorer 
sections in public decision making. This empowerment of the poor is expected to sustain itself 
beyond the life of the Project. The organizations put in place by the Project are expected to be 
institutionalized in the target districts and expanded to other districts. The Project is, therefore, 
expected  to  have  benefits  beyond  its  implementation  period  and  area.  Since  the  Project  will 
have a significant impact on reducing isolation by improving access to markets and increasing 
the  flow  of  information,  the  Project  will  address  social  problems  that  are  specifically  related  to 
the  isolation  of  areas.  Furthermore,  the  Project’s  attention  to  the  formation  of  homogenous 

 21 

groups and ensuring that the poorest are represented in decision making groups will ensure that 
activities  are  implemented  that  are  specifically  targeted  to  the  disadvantaged  sections  of  the 
communities. The Project will not entail any resettlement. Where project investments cause any 
households  to  lose  assets,  income,  or  livelihoods,  the  households  will  be  adequately 
compensated for the loss. 
 
74. 
The  high  involvement  of  women  in  agriculture  as  farmers,  sharecroppers,  and 
agricultural  laborers  means  that  women  will  directly  benefit  from  project  investments.  Specific 
assurances have been formulated to mitigate the possible exclusion of women and other more 
disadvantaged groups from actively participating in project activities. The Project stipulates that 
half  the  members  of  the  PIVFs  will  be  women.  This  will  increase  the  importance  accorded  to 
women’s  activities  in  investment  selection.  The  development  of  socialization  materials  in  local 
languages  will  increase  the  reflection  of  women’s  views  in  investment  proposals.  Indicators  of 
the  successful  functioning  of  the  groups  will  be  high  women’s  attendance  rates  at  meetings, 
their  decision  to  start  new  group  activities  on  their  own,  and  the  spontaneous  emergence  of 
women’s groups desiring to join the Project. Monitoring and evaluation mechanisms will be built 
into the Project so that activities can be continuously assessed to verify the extent to which men 
and women farmers are reached with the different types of project services and resources.  
 
D. 

Risks  

75. 
Years  of  top-down  centralized  agricultural  investments  have  left  farmers  with  little 
capacity  to  innovate.  Little  village  expertise  exists  in  implementing  investments  and  managing 
funds. The success of the Project will depend upon (i) the effectiveness of NGOs to train and 
assist  village  facilitators,  and  (ii)  the  establishment  of  effective  VPICs.  The  Project  will  pay 
careful  attention  to  the  training  of  village  facilitators  and  VPICs,  and  to  the  selection  of  local 
NGOs/community organizations and their training. 
 
Self-help  projects  sometimes  do  not  work  because  beneficiaries  do  not  have  the 
76. 
expertise  to  undertake  activities  they  have  themselves  identified.  Effective  links  with  local 
agencies that can provide technical expertise will be crucial to project success. Such direct links 
to  farmers  have  not  been  the  norm,  particularly  for  government  agencies.  The  efficient 
functioning  of  the  DCC  and  the  initiative  of  the  NGOs/community  organizations  will  be  key  to 
forging  links  between  farmers  and  sources  of  technical  expertise.  The  first  year  of  project 
implementation  will  be  spent  establishing  such  links  and  identifying  the  modalities  for 
partnerships between farmer groups and external agencies. 
 
77. 
NGOs have sometimes had a tense relationship with external funding agencies and the 
Government. A healthy working relationship between NGOs and the PIUs, DCCs, PCMU, and 
PIVF are essential for project success. The relative autonomy accorded to the NGOs, the direct 
control of investment funds by farmers, and the monitoring of the Project by independent groups 
will  reduce  some  of  the  tensions  between  government  agencies  and  NGOs.  However,  some 
local  friction  could  still  arise  in  some  project  areas  and  this  will  have  to  be  resolved  through 
mediation by local NGOs, the national NGO, and perhaps by ADB missions. 
 
78. 
As with almost every project, the risk of appropriation of benefits by the more powerful 
sections of society is a risk also in this Project. To mitigate this risk, the Project will ensure that 
decision making groups empower poor farmers. The Project will attempt to mitigate this risk by 
maximizing the transparency of the process and building in adequate accounting, auditing, and 
reporting  requirements  without  placing  undue  administrative  burden  on  poor  villages.  Strong 
supervision  by  ADB  will  be  key  in  identifying  problems  when  they  arise.  The  Project  will  also 

 22 

establish a complaints and grievance system. Complaints received will be investigated quickly 
to  establish  confidence  in  the  system.  The  Project  will  specifically  support  an  independent 
ombudsperson and monitoring by an independent group. 
 
The  complexity  of  the  Project  makes  its  success  crucially  contingent  upon  efficient 
79. 
implementation.  Centralized  management  of  such  a  complex  project  is  impossible  without 
incurring  excessive  project  management  costs.  However,  the  use  of  NGOs/community 
organizations with ongoing community partnerships is a novel approach to resolving problems 
of  managing  local  implementation.  Appropriate  monitoring  and  reporting  formats  will  be 
established to ensure that the decentralized implementation of the Project does not detract from 
its intended benefits. 
 
Decentralization  has  resulted  in  uncertainties  related  to  financial  autonomy,  revenue-
80. 
raising  powers  of  districts,  and  regulations  on  the  use  of  external  funds.  These  uncertainties 
could potentially cause delays in project implementation and friction between central and district 
governments. Particularly, in the absence of guidelines on the responsibility for the repayment

12. 
The village plans, from these sample project areas, have identified a number of activities 
or  subprojects,  such  as  (i)  construction  of  village  to  market  road  links;  (ii)  provision  for  better 
communications,  training,  extension,  and  finance  fund  management,  which  could  involve  the 
construction of suitable buildings; (iii) upgrading of, or installation of new local irrigation systems; 
and (iv) introduction of new and better seeds and livestock including cattle, goats, and in some 
areas, pigs that could involve the construction of stalls.   
 
13. 
No  major  impacts  are  associated  with  the  design,  construction,  or  operation  of  the 
proposed subproject. Most of the impacts are associated with infrastructure developments that 
are associated with rehabilitation and improvement of  local roads and irrigation systems.  
 
14. 
The  potential  impacts  of  road  rehabilitation  and  improvement  into  village  fringe  areas 
where  shifting  agriculture  is  practiced  can  be  high,  and  exceed  direct  impacts  from  logging  or 
forest product harvesting. The most dangerous will occur from burning, if others are induced to 
follow. The geology of the dry areas is commonly such that there is fragile soil and burning can 
irreversibly destroy stable vegetation. Therefore, road rehabilitation carried out within the Project 
will  have  to  meet  the  general  criterion,  to  eventually  make  upper  slope  shifting  agriculture 
unattractive  for  villagers.  The  mitigation  measures  for  road  rehabilitation  and  improvement  will 
include (i) adherence to simple safety and operating procedures to limit and contain discarding 
of fuel, oil, and solid debris from servicing equipment; (ii) adherence to designed road locations; 
(iii)  adherence  to  a  designed  strategy  for  containing  and  spreading  spoil  to  avoid  dangerous 
stockpiling;  and  (iv)  adherence  to  the  designed  locations  and  specifications  of  culverts 
discharging storm water. 
 
15. 
Dams  and  canals  must  be  constructed  to  the  specifications  developed  for  each 
individual  site,  and  the  location  of  each  structure  has  to  be  confirmed  by  the  project  manager 
and the civil engineer before construction begins. Impacts arising from a small dam failure can 
include death and the destruction of downstream property in addition to the value of losses of 
the structure, contained fish, lost crop, and lost future crop potential. 
 
Some  village  plans  include  increasing  livestock  numbers  as  a  significant  component. 
16. 
Adequate  preparation  is  required  before  a  large  increase  in  herd  size  can  be  accommodated 
within the village framework. In particular, feed must be planted at least 2, and up to 6 months 
before livestock are obtained to ensure there is sufficient to eat. Fencing has to be adequate to 
contain the animals if they are not in stalls with provision for fresh water and fodder. Should any 
one of these requirements not be met, monetary loss is likely flowing from degeneration in the 
herd  and  secondary  impacts  on  adjacent  lands  on  to  which  livestock  are  turned  out.  The 
technical  service  groups  will  be  responsible  for  making  recommendations  for  village  plans  to 
address these issues and for village plans to then implement the required measures.

high poverty impact. If the economic returns resulting from quantifiable but uncertain benefits of 
village plans are in the range of 15% to 20%, as expected, then the poverty impact ratio will be 
in the range of 3.7 to 1.8, falling as overall net present value rises to increase the denominator 
in the formula. Over a similar range, the ratio of net benefits of the poor to the present value of 
project costs would rise from about 66% to 91%, as benefits rise in relation to the fixed project 
costs.  Village  investment  proposals  reviewed  suggest  typical  financial  returns  to  village 
investments  of  the  order  of  25%  to  give  project  economic  returns  providing  a  poverty  impact 
ratio  of  the  order  or  2.5  and  a  ratio  of  net  benefits  to  the  poor  at  some  74%  of  project  costs. 
Although  uncertain  in  detail,  the  range  suggests  the  Project  is  soundly  poverty  focused,  and 
efficient and effective in delivering benefits to the poor.
